items.description: Tidal Thames riverside from Putney Bridge to Teddington Weir
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex

floodArea.county: Greater London, Hammersmith and Fulham, Hounslow, Richmond upon Thames, Wandsworth

items.message:
River levels are expected to be high as a result of spring tides.

The forecast high tide at Richmond is 4.70mAOD at 16:45 on 09/10/2025.

Flooding of low-lying roads and footpaths is expected, which may exist for one to two hours either side of high tide. Flooding of properties is not expected.

We believe there is a possibility of flooding for Putney Embankment (SW15), Chiswick Mall and Strand on the Green (W4), Thames Bank at Mortlake (SW14), Ranelagh Drive (TW1), Friars Lane and Water Lane (TW9), Riverside and The Embankment at Twickenham, and the Towpath below Teddington Lock. 

Astronomical tide levels are peaking. The river flow at Teddington Weir is low for this time of year at 10 cubic metres per second and is steady. We anticipate the flows to remain low for the next five days.

We are closely monitoring the situation.

This message will be updated by 20:00 on 09/10/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Tidal River Avon at Bristol, Pill and Shirehampton

floodArea.county: City of Bristol, North Somerset, South Gloucestershire

items.message:
Higher than normal spring tides are forecast this evening. Flooding of roads and low-lying land is possible, property flooding is not expected.
The forecast high-water is 9:45 PM today 09/10/25 with a level of 7.48 mAOD and a Force 3 North-Westerly wind. Times are local and refer to the high-water time at Avonmouth, mAOD is height above average sea level. Conditions may apply one to two hours either side of the high tide. 
Areas most at risk include the tidal River Avon from Sea Mills to Conham in Bristol and between the Avonmouth Bridge and Shirehampton Park including Pill and Shirehampton.
We are closely monitoring the situation and closing flood gates at Pill. Please be careful along low-lying land near watercourses where conditions may be hazardous.
This message will be updated tomorrow 10/10/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: North Devon coast from Hartland Point to Lynmouth
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message: The risk of flooding from the sea has now reduced, however, standing water may remain, so take care near coastal paths and promenades.

items.description: Mersey Estuary at Warrington
items.message:
High tides are expected to reach the flood alert threshold overnight which may lead to flooding between 02:00 AM and 03:30 AM on 10/10/2025.  The impacted locations are:
 
Fiddlers Ferry, peaking around 02:45 AM
 
Eastford Road, peaking around 03:00 AM
 
Arpley Bridge, peaking around 03:15 AM
 
It is possible that river levels will also affect Arpley Road under the railway bridge. 
 
Following this, no other tides are expected to reach the flood alert threshold in this current sequence.
We are closely monitoring the situation.
This message will be updated by 10:00 AM on 10/10/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Coast at North Morecambe Bay
items.message:
High spring tides are expected until Friday 10 October. Flooding of roads and low lying land is possible, property flooding is not expected.

The early morning tide at 01:45 AM on Friday 10 October is forecast to reach flood alert levels at Sandside and Arnside. The following high tide at 14:05 PM on Friday 10 October, and subsequent high tides, are not forecast to reach flood alert level. Tide levels may be high 2 hours either side of peak level timings.

Areas that may be affected are the Coast at North Morecambe Bay from Roosebeck to Carnforth including low lying areas around Ulverston, Canal Foot, Greenodd, Haverthwaite, Flookburgh, Grange-over-Sands, Levens, Milnthorpe, Sandside, Arnside and Silverdale.
 
Be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as tidal floodwater is expected to impact these low lying areas. Do not attempt to drive through floodwater.
 
This message will be updated by 10:00 AM on Friday 10 October, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Tyne estuary

floodArea.county: Gateshead, Newcastle upon Tyne, North Tyneside, South Tyneside

items.message:
Flooding is possible around the peak of the high tide on Thursday evening (09/10/2025) at 5:30 PM.

Flooding is also possible on the subsequent high tide at 5:45 AM on Friday morning (10/10/2025).

Areas most at risk include Newcastle Quayside.

Please note levels are not expected to be as high as they were on Thursday morning.  
 
Tidal conditions are expected to improve following the high tide on Friday morning after which no further flooding is expected.

We are closely monitoring the situation. Avoid roads, footpaths and carparks at Newcastle Quayside, which may be flooded.

This message will be updated by 10:00 AM on 10/10/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Wye Estuary in Gloucestershire
items.message:
A flood alert has been issued due to a period of high tides. 
Tides will be at their highest around 21:30 this evening 09/10/25 and at 09:45 on Friday morning 10/10/25. Flooding of roads and low-lying land adjacent to the Wye Estuary from Redbrook to Chepstow is expected at the time of high tides, however conditions may apply a few hours either side of the high tides. 
Predicted peaks this evening Thursday 09/10/25: Newport 6.9m to 7.3m around 21:30 and Avonmouth 7.3m to 7.6m around 21:45. 
Predicted peaks tomorrow morning Friday 09/10/25: Newport 6.6m to 6.9m around 09:45 and Avonmouth 7.0m to 7.2m around 10:00. 
We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. This message will be updated by 11:00 on 10/10/25, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Somerset coast at Porlock Weir
items.message:
High spring tides may lead to flooding this evening. Flooding of roads and low lying land is possible, however property flooding is not expected.

The highest tide level is expected at the coastline between Gore Point and Hurlstone Point, including Porlock Weir, at 9:15 PM on 09/10/2025. Flooding is possible an hour and a half either side of this time.

The detailed tidal forecast for those who use it is for a peak level at Hinkley Point of 6.37 mAODN at 9:15 PM on 09/10/2025, with Northerly force 4 winds. (mAODN is height above average sea level.)
 
We are closely monitoring the situation. Be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous. Further flood alerts may be issued for this current sequence of high Spring tides.

This message will be updated by 1:00 PM on 10/10/2025, or as the situation changes.
